issues.description: The problem statement (and UML) specify addGuestStudents(int) as the method to implement, and the solution implements public void addGuestStudents(int). However, the template defines a different signature: public void addGuestStudents(int numberOfNewGuestStudents, boolean validateInput) (an extra boolean parameter). This parameter mismatch across artifacts is structural: students following the problem statement will implement addGuestStudents(int), but the template's stub uses a different signature which will confuse students and may cause compilation/signature inconsistencies with tests or the intended solution.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the template method signature match the problem statement and the solution by changing the template stub to: public void addGuestStudents(int numberOfNewGuestStudents) { /* TODO */ }  Alternatively, if the extra boolean was intentional, update the problem statement and the solution to require addGuestStudents(int, boolean) and document the purpose of the boolean parameter. Prefer aligning the template to the current problem statement/solution to avoid student confusion.

issues.description: The problem statement (and UML) specifies a method addGuestStudents(int) that accepts a single integer parameter, and the solution implementation provides exactly that signature. However, the template stub declares addGuestStudents(int numberOfNewGuestStudents, boolean validateInput) — i.e., the same method name but with an extra boolean parameter. This discrepancy between template and the problem/solution creates a clear mapping mismatch: students reading the task expect to implement or use addGuestStudents(int) but the provided starter code has a different signature, which can cause confusion and compilation/test failures.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the template method signature match the problem statement and the solution: change the template declaration to public void addGuestStudents(int numberOfNewGuestStudents) { /* ... */ }. If input validation is desired, either implement it internally (without changing the signature) or add an overloaded helper method; avoid changing the primary signature defined in the task/UML so students can map requirements to code unambiguously.
